newsitem.title: USA: U.S. broadcasters may get to keep some airwave rights.
newsitem.headline: U.S. broadcasters may get to keep some airwave rights.

text.p: Budget legislation making its way through Congress would let television broadcasters keep a valuable piece of the airwaves they are supposed to return to the government after the transition to digital TV.

Supporters say the measure, approved late on Wednesday by a House panel, is meant to ensure that consumers who do not buy a high-definition digital TV set will not be saddled with a worthless analogue set unable to receive digital broadcasts.
It would allow broadcasters to keep their existing analogue broadcast licenses beyond 2006 if 5 percent of their audience relies exclusively on existing over-the-air analogue signals.

"It's designed to be a safety valve to ensure that nobody's TV set goes black because they couldn't afford to buy a digital TV set," said Ken Johnson, a spokesman for Representative W.J. (Billy) Tauzin, a Louisiana Republican.

But critics charge it would leave the government without a guarantee that TV stations will return the analogue spectrum to the Federal Communications Commission for auction. And they say it would dampen eventual bidding for those airwaves.
New FCC rules require the licenses be returned by 2006 so the spectrum can be made available to communications firms for other uses, following the conversion to digital TV.
"The government will never see that spectrum," said Gigi Sohn of the Media Access Project, a public-interest law firm. "It's a very backhanded way of reversing what the FCC did two months ago."
The fate of the legislation is unclear. But the analogue license provision is likely to face scepticism in the Senate.
A spokeswoman for Sen. John McCain, an Arizona Republican who chairs the committee responsible for dealing with such matters, said the measure "would create a large loophole."

It comes soon after the FCC gave TV stations digital-TV licenses free of charge on the assumption the analogue permits would be returned. McCain and other critics called the free digital licenses a multibillion dollar giveaway.
The budget measure approved by the House Commerce Committee is part of a bill meant to implement the fiscal 1998 budget accord agreed to by President Clinton and cleared by Congress.
The agreement calls for the government to raise $26.3 billion through airwave auctions -- including $5.4 billion from the sale of the analogue spectrum in the year 2001.
The auction would be made ahead of the 2006 target date set by the FCC for the return of the analogue spectrum.

FCC Chairman Reed Hundt said the provision to allow TV stations to keep the airwaves if 5 percent of their audience continued to rely on analogue signals would hurt the auction, thereby robbing the government of money.
"The uncertainy created by such mandatory license extensions could discourage potential future users from bidding for this spectrum," he told Representative Tauzin in a letter.
But Tauzin spokesman Ken Johnson said: "None of us have a crystal ball to know for certain by what date consumers are going to embrace digital TV. That's why you need a little wiggle room."
